By BUD FORREST
EDDIE DUCHIN has been signed by
the June Week Committee to manufacture the melody for the Senior Ball which,
by the way, is to take place on June 14,
the day after Commencement. Duchin
uses nine men in his band at the Central
Park Casino, but will bring twelve men
to Baltimore, thereby augmenting the
band to ballroom size. This band offers
a smooth soft rhythm,similar to the style
of Will Osborne, Freddy Martin, and
William Scotti. Although Duchin's band
will be quite audible in a fair-sized
crowd at the Alcazar, Eddie knows he
can pack them in. Hence the band's enlargement.

Orchestra Has Already Appeared At Many College
Proms
Don Redman's famous Connie's
Inn and Columbia Broadcasing
System orchestra has been definitely secured for the Varsity
Club dance to be given at the
Alcazar Ballroom, May 20, from
9 P.M. to 2 A.M. This affair will
mark the band's first appearance
in Baltimore.
The price of tickets will be
$1.65 per couple or single subscription if they are bought in advance, and $2.20 per couple or
stag if they are purchased at the
door. Tickets may be secured
from any member of the Varsity
Club.
Besides the main ball-room, the
Blue Room, attractively arranged
as a lounge, will be used together
with the gymnasium, in which
tables will be placed and refreshments sold at moderate prices.

Price For Cotillion Dance
Tomorrow Is Changed
To $1.10
In a recent statement, Jack
Henderson, chairman of the Cotillion Board, announced that
tickets for the remaining dances
this year will be $1.10. This
change in price was necessary because of the presence of counterfeit
admission tickets on the campus.
in connection with the Hopkins
Mt. Washington lacrosse game,
the next dance will be held tomorrow night. The Townsmen
will furnish the music.
The dance originally scheduled
for May 21 has been cancelled so
as to assure a greater attendance
at the Varsity Club dance which
will be held May 20.

DENTISTRY

Dr. Florence Rena Sabin, professor of histology at the Johns Hopkins University, lectured at Goucher College May 2 on "Cells in Relation to Tuberculosis."
At present a member of the
Rockefeller Institute for Research,
Dr. Sabin was the first woman to
be awarded the M.D. degree at the
Hopkins Medical School.

Support Solicited

The dance proceeds will be used
by the Athletic Association to
bolster the Varsity Club scholarship fund, which has been sadly
depleted due to recent bank failures. The committee solicits the
whole-hearted attendance of the
entire student body since the
cause is so worthy of its support.
Redman organized his dance
band a year ago and since then
has been heard regularly from
Connie's Inn in Harlem via the
Columbia network. His novelty
in composing and arranging has
made his orchestra one of the outstanding units on the radio. The
baod has already made successful
appearances at the Syracuse
Senior Ball, Cornell Junior Prom,
Lehigh Interfraternity Ball and
other collegiate affairs.

Committee; Wagner In Charge
Of Frosh Program
At the formal installation of the
Y. M. C. A. Cabinet before the University Supper Club last Tuesday,
John G. Weeks announced the appointments for the coming year.
Keith Conning will head the University Supper Club Committee.
The freshman program will be in
charge of J. Donald Wagner.
Appointments to the Johns Hopkins "Y" News: Peter Leary, editor; David Levy, business manager; and Douglas Williamson, managing editor. The Handbook is to
be edited by J. Donald Wagner,
with Charles E. Torsch as assistant
editor.

EDDIE DUCHIN has been signed by
the June Week Committee to manufacture the melody for the Senior Ball which,
by the way, is to take place on June 14,
the day after Commencement. Duchin
uses nine men in his band at the Central
Park Casino, but will bring twelve men
to Baltimore, thereby augmenting the
band to ballroom size. This band offers
a smooth soft rhythm,similar to the style
of Will Osborne, Freddy Martin, and
William Scotti. Although Duchin's band
will be quite audible in a fair-sized
crowd at the Alcazar, Eddie knows he
can pack them in. Hence the band's enlargement.

DON REDMAN'S BAND
DEFINITELY SECURED
BY VARSITY CLUB
Affair To Be Held In The
Ballroom Of Alcazar,
May 20
PROCEEDS TO GO
TO ATHLETIC ASS'N.
Orchestra Has Already Appeared At Many College
Proms
Don Redman's famous Connie's
Inn and Columbia Broadcasing
System orchestra has been definitely secured for the Varsity
Club dance to be given at the
Alcazar Ballroom, May 20, from
9 P.M. to 2 A.M. This affair will
mark the band's first appearance
in Baltimore.
The price of tickets will be
$1.65 per couple or single subscription if they are bought in advance, and $2.20 per couple or
stag if they are purchased at the
door. Tickets may be secured
from any member of the Varsity
Club.
Besides the main ball-room, the
Blue Room, attractively arranged
as a lounge, will be used together
with the gymnasium, in which
tables will be placed and refreshments sold at moderate prices.

Price For Cotillion Dance
Tomorrow Is Changed
To $1.10
In a recent statement, Jack
Henderson, chairman of the Cotillion Board, announced that
tickets for the remaining dances
this year will be $1.10. This
change in price was necessary because of the presence of counterfeit
admission tickets on the campus.
in connection with the Hopkins
Mt. Washington lacrosse game,
the next dance will be held tomorrow night. The Townsmen
will furnish the music.
The dance originally scheduled
for May 21 has been cancelled so
as to assure a greater attendance
at the Varsity Club dance which
will be held May 20.

DENTISTRY

Dr. Florence Rena Sabin, professor of histology at the Johns Hopkins University, lectured at Goucher College May 2 on "Cells in Relation to Tuberculosis."

Rockefeller Institute for Research,
Dr. Sabin was the first woman to
be awarded the M.D. degree at the
Hopkins Medical School.

Support Solicited

The dance proceeds will be used
by the Athletic Association to
bolster the Varsity Club scholarship fund, which has been sadly
depleted due to recent bank failures. The committee solicits the
whole-hearted attendance of the
entire student body since the
cause is so worthy of its support.
Redman organized his dance
band a year ago and since then
has been heard regularly from
Connie's Inn in Harlem via the
Columbia network. His novelty
in composing and arranging has
made his orchestra one of the outstanding units on the radio. The
baod has already made successful
appearances at the Syracuse
Senior Ball, Cornell Junior Prom,
Lehigh Interfraternity Ball and
other collegiate affairs.

Conning To Head Supper Club
Committee; Wagner In Charge
Of Frosh Program
At the formal installation of the
Y. M. C. A. Cabinet before the University Supper Club last Tuesday,
John G. Weeks announced the appointments for the coming year.
Keith Conning will head the University Supper Club Committee.
The freshman program will be in
charge of J. Donald Wagner.
Appointments to the Johns Hopkins "Y" News: Peter Leary, editor; David Levy, business manager; and Douglas Williamson, managing editor. The Handbook is to
be edited by J. Donald Wagner,
with Charles E. Torsch as assistant
editor.
